frameDefinitions: A Patient is committed to the care of a medical Facility by a proper Authority.

This frame deals with a Speaker communicating a reply or response, a Message, to some prior communication or action, the Trigger.  '' 'The landlord has not yet replied in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.

The words in this frame have to do with a Speaker asking an Addressee a question which calls for a reply (as opposed to making a request which calls for an action on the part of the Addressee).  '' 'We asked Ruby what kind of food they ate.'
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.
This frame concerns Communicators communicating with each other with the aid of a Means of communication such as a telephone.
frameExamples: Ten years after Abraham Lincoln's assassination, a Chicago court declared his 56-year-old widow Mary insane and <t>committed</t> her to a mental institution.
The landlord has not yet <t>replied</t> in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.DNI
We <t>asked</t> Ruby what kind of food they ate.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
listRoleDefinitions: The person who is committed to a facility with a view towards helping them mentally or physically.
The facility where the <fen>Patient</fen> is taken for treatment.

The <fen>Authority</fen> is the actor carrying out the institutionalization with proper legal authorization, either invested into them in general by the government or granted due to power of attorney over the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The time interval during which the institutionalization happens.
The location in which the <fen>Facility</fen> is situated.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that communicates the reply or response. It is expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of a <t>Target</t> verb or as the Genitive modifier of a <t>Target</t> noun:
This is the person to whom the response is communicated.  When expressed, this role occurs as the direct object of a <t>Target</t> verb, or in a prepositional phrase introduced by 'to':
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a direct quote or a clause.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs quite rarely in this frame and usually only as a PP Complement of a noun <t>Target</t>:
The <fen>Trigger</fen> is the prior communication or action to which a response is given. It can occur as an NP Object or a PP Complement.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  makes a verbal response.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
The person asking a question generally occurs as the External Argument of verb and noun targets:

The Addressee is most frequently the NP Object of a target verb.  However, with the verb <ment>inquire</ment>, Addressee can only occur as an <ment>of</ment>-PP and with a noun target, Addressee occurs in a PP Complement or as a possessive :
The Message, or content of the question, usually takes the form of a direct quote or an embedded question with a verb target:
Topic occurs very frequently in this frame with both noun and verb targets. It generally occurs as a PP Complement:
The time at which the questioning occurs.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.

This role is the person who uses the <fen>Means</fen> of communication to deliver the <fen>Message</fen> to the Addressee. The Speaker is normally expressed as the External Argument of target verbs, or as the Genitive modifier of  nouns.

<fen>Addressee</fen> is the person to whom the <fen>Message</fen> is communicated. When this role is expressed, it often appears in a prepositional phrase introduced by to, or as the direct object, or as the first object in a double object construction.
This role identifies the content that the <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
<fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is typically expressed as a PP Complement headed by about.

This Frame Element refers to the Instrument of Communication that is used by the <fen>Communicator</fen> (and <fen>Addressee</fen>). Each LU in this frame incorporates the <fen>Means</fen> frame element.
listRoleExamples:
Buffy's got this hospital phobia because her caring parents institutionalized
<fex>her</fex> for a while before she moved to Sunnydale.

Unfortunately for Mrs. Lincoln, her son, Robert, institutionalized her <fex>in the
Batavia Asylum</fex> shortly after the visit to St. Charles.
Goodrum then went to see <fex>a private doctor</fex> <fex>who</fex> hospitalized him.
<fex>Later</fex> her mother became depressed and was institutionalized.

The widow of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. suffered a stroke on Wednesday, and was
hospitalized <fex>in Atlanta</fex>.
<fex>Sue</fex> responded to the objection convincingly.
Sue answered <fex>Bob</fex> immediately.
<fex>'I can't help you,'</fex> Sue answered.
My boss still hasn't given me an answer <fex>about a promotion</fex>.
Sue answered <fex>the question</fex>.
A reminder letter was sent to all nonrespondents who had not replied <fex>after 28 days</fex>.
This was how Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalithaa responded <fex>in the Assembly</fex> on November 5, 2003.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>Pat</fex> quizzed me about where I had been.
Pat questioned <fex>me</fex> about where I had been.
<fex>'What are you doing?'</fex> Kim inquired.
Pat inquired <fex>about train times</fex>.
I inquired <fex>yesterday</fex>.
<fex>Evelyn</fex> spoke feelingly about what happened.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Evelyn spoke candidly <fex>about her past</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.
<fex>The President</fex> cabled his assistant to cancel all of his appointments.
The President cabled <fex>his assistant</fex> to cancel all other engagements.
